heading: DANIEL ALEXANDER
overlap_from_previous: Q      And what does Target Wait Time do?
A      Target Wait Time feature, as defined in the WIFI 6 or 11X standard,
Page 87
paragraphs: defines a capability that allows the AP and the station to negotiate on what's called a service period.
That's a period of time where the station and AP are expected to do their transmit/receive functionality.
And out of that TWT service period, the station can go and do any other activity.
It can go connect to a different AP or do what's called a multi-visual MAC activity or any off channel activity, scan or something else it wants to do with its resources.
And if it doesn't have anything else to do, it can also just go to sleep and wait until the next deliver service period.
This is all left for -- left for the implementation.
22 So that's the standard 23 definition only.  Again, I'm repeating that 24 this functionality that I described is not 25 supported by Intel's products.

And on that special testing version, actually the same version that's run by WIFI Alliance, we saw that the APs do not support what's expected in order to allow TWT to be a power saving feature.

Q      Okay, so let's break that down for a moment.

With respect to the Chrome driver code, that's public or not?

A      The Chrome driver code is public.

Q      And what information is there in the public Chrome driver code as to whether Intel implements TWT?

A      So, you can see in the text describing the bug fix that TWT is being disabled.

You can see the actual code the bit in the H extended capability reports that tells the AP that the station supports TWT.

So in the fix, you can see that was removed, actually removed.  Instead of reporting in the bug, it was reported that it was set to 1.

That line is deleted, and basically the report to the AP is indicating a zero, meaning the station is not supporting TWT after that fix.

heading: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure Rule 30
overlap_from_previous: Page 38
paragraphs: (e) Review By the Witness; Changes.

Review; Statement of Changes. On request by the deponent or a party before the deposition is completed, the deponent must be allowed 30 days after being notified by the officer that the transcript or recording is available in which: (A) to review the transcript or recording; and if there are changes in form or substance, to
(B) sign a statement listing the changes and the reasons for making them.

Changes Indicated in the Officer's Certificate. The officer must note in the certificate prescribed by Rule 30(f)(1) whether a review was requested and, if so, must attach any changes the deponent makes during the 30-day period.

DISCLAIMER:  THE FOREGOING FEDERAL PROCEDURE RULES ARE PROVIDED FOR INFORMATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY. THE ABOVE RULES ARE CURRENT AS OF APRIL 1, 2019.  PLEASE REFER TO THE APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES OF CIVIL PROCEDURE FOR UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION.
